body.p: Checkstyle is configured using properties, which are string representations. This document describes how these string representations are mapped to typed properties.

section.name: integer
section.p: This property represents an integer. The string representation is parsed using the java.lang.Integer class.

section.name: string
section.p: This property represents a string. The literal string representation is used.

section.name: boolean
section.p: This property represents a boolean. The default value is false. The following string representations will map to true:
Anything else will map to false.

section.name: stringSet
section.p: This property represents a set of strings. The string representation is parsed as a set of comma (',') separated strings.

section.name: intSet
section.p: This property represents a set of integers. The string representation is parsed as a set of comma (',') separated integers that are parsed using the java.lang.Integer class.

section.name: regexp
section.p: This property represents a regular expression. The string representation is parsed using java.util.regex package.

section.name: parenPad
section.p: This property represents the policy for padding with white space. The following table describes the valid options:

section.name: lcurly
section.p: This property represents the policy for checking the placement of a left curly brace ('{'). The following table describes the valid options:

tr.td: Option
Definition

If the brace will fit on the first line of the statement, taking into account maximum line length, then apply eol rule. Otherwise apply the nl rule. nlow is a mnemonic for "new line on wrap". For the example above Checkstyle will enforce:
if (condition) { ...
But for a statement spanning multiple lines, Checkstyle will enforce:
if (condition1 && condition2 && condition3 && condition4) { ...
